Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Flame-Assisted Chemical Vapor Deposition for Energy Storage Electrode Fabrication

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Steady baseload power, based on renewable energy, requires widespread implementation of energy storage technology. This project is to develop a flame synthesis process for producing energy storage electrodes. Such flame-based fabrication can reduce production steps and improve sustainability. Rapid synthesis and dry production are key strengths of flame synthesis. The control and selectivity of flame synthesis will allow for fabrication of high-performing energy storage electrodes. It is anticipated that the flame-based method developed in this project will have the potential to produce energy storage electrodes on an industrial scale. This project will also lead to the creation of a course, "Scalable Manufacturing of Emerging Technologies", which will expose students to manufacturing methods relevant to emerging technologies.

This project is focused on flame synthesis of manganese oxide and carbon nano-materials in a process that combines deposition into functional films. Relevant to energy storage electrodes, this work involves various fundamental studies, including a) thermodynamics and kinetics of manganese oxide and carbon nanoparticle flame synthesis, b) relationship between nano-material structure / film-morphology and electrochemical performance, and c) aerosol dynamics governing fabrication of multi-component films for energy storage electrodes. A new thermodynamic analysis for the surface energy effect at flame conditions will be applied and kinetics of Mn oxidation and carbon sp2 formation will be studied. Reacting flow simulations of flame synthesis in stagnation flow will be connected to aerosol dynamics of porous film deposition. A dual-flame CVD process for fabrication of Mn oxide / carbon films will be developed for energy storage electrodes having maximum ionic and electronic conductivity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

ProgramElement.Text: Proc Sys, Reac Eng & Mol Therm

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

POR.DRECONTENT:
Fabrication of energy storage electrodes by flame-assisted chemical vapor deposition was demonstrated. Films of energy storage active material was deposited from the flame and directly characterized after the one-step synthesis process. Viable energy storage performance was observed and avenues for further optimizing energy storage capacity were determined. The energy storage fabrication was enable by several fundamental studies on formation and growth of manganese oxide and carbon nanoparticles in flames.

The evolution in carbon structure for soot produced at flame temperatures higher than conventional flames (T > 2100 K) is a unique area of study supported in this project. Our flame synthesis method produces soot having carbon structural order approaching high-defect carbon based on new Raman spectroscopy, color-ratio pyrometry and HR-TEM analysis. For manganese oxide, we have established a global thermodynamic model to describe nucleation and phase stability of flame-formed manganese oxide nanoparticles. Known size-dependent equilibrium parameters were successfully applied to the Mn-MnO-Mn3O4-Mn2O3-MnO2 system and compared to experimental flame synthesis products. The nucleation mechanism for Mn(g) + 1/2 O2 (g) -> MnO (s) was proposed by us and solid experimental evidence was obtained to validate this global description of the gas-to-particle conversion for manganese oxide nanoparticles. The relatively high-temperature of premixed laminar stagnation flames introduces a thermodynamic barrier to nucleation for manganese oxides and this was quantified in terms of the Kelvin effect with corroborating experimental evidence. The SpraySyn standardized spray flame nanoparticle synthesis system was installed in our lab and high-throughput production of carbon nanoparticles was demonstrated.

Modified by: Joaquin Camacho

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Fabrication of energy storage electrodes by flame-assisted chemical vapor deposition was demonstrated. Films of energy storage active material was deposited from the flame and directly characterized after the one-step synthesis process. Viable energy storage performance was observed and avenues for further optimizing energy storage capacity were determined. The energy storage fabrication was enable by several fundamental studies on formation and growth of manganese oxide and carbon nanoparticles in flames. The evolution in carbon structure for soot produced at flame temperatures higher than conventional flames (T > 2100 K) is a unique area of study supported in this project. Our flame synthesis method produces soot having carbon structural order approaching high-defect carbon based on new Raman spectroscopy, color-ratio pyrometry and HR-TEM analysis. For manganese oxide, we have established a global thermodynamic model to describe nucleation and phase stability of flame-formed manganese oxide nanoparticles. Known size-dependent equilibrium parameters were successfully applied to the Mn-MnO-Mn3O4-Mn2O3-MnO2 system and compared to experimental flame synthesis products. The nucleation mechanism for Mn(g) + 1/2 O2 (g) -> MnO (s) was proposed by us and solid experimental evidence was obtained to validate this global description of the gas-to-particle conversion for manganese oxide nanoparticles. The relatively high-temperature of premixed laminar stagnation flames introduces a thermodynamic barrier to nucleation for manganese oxides and this was quantified in terms of the Kelvin effect with corroborating experimental evidence. The SpraySyn standardized spray flame nanoparticle synthesis system was installed in our lab and high-throughput production of carbon nanoparticles was demonstrated.
